text: ...British, fifties, a melodrama. We're looking at an ACTRESS - glamorous, young - but very much in the back ground of the scene - a secretary typing at her desk.
A YOUNG BOY sits watching the film, his clothes and the room around him telling us this is England in the 1960s. is staring raptly at the actress.
All my life I've been a Looky- Loo.
We are CLOSE on an extremely handsome YOUNG MAN staring past us with a dazzling smile.

My name's Sidney Young. I'm a journalist...a hack. (Beat) Yeah, that...that isn't me. We PAN right and down to our hero - SIDNEY YOUNG - thirties, an odd-ball with a knack for getting people to dislike him.

This is me at the Golden Globe Awards in L.A. this year. That's my Armani tuxedo. That's a Rolex Sea-Dweller 4000 watch I'm wearing. Still in SLOW-MOTION we TRACK BACK and see that Sidney is at a table with several other people, all staring raptly past us to the stage which is out of shot.
Those people all around me - they're all famous. They're my friends. Beside him sits a beautiful young woman - SOPHIE MAES (20's). 2.

That's the actress Sophie Maes. This morning she told me she would let me have sex with her if she won the Best Actress Award. Still in SLOW MOTION, Sophie suddenly covers her face wit her hands and begins to stand.

She just won the Best Actress Award. Sophie walks out of the shot. Still sporting the fixed smile, Sidney claps in SLO-MO along with everyone else in the room. We TRACK away from Sidney past tables of CELEBRITIES towards an EXIT.
My life didn't used to be like this. We PUSH THROUGH the EXIT DOORS and find ourselves impossibly looking at...

...a crowd of FANS held back from us by a red rope, crani their necks to see us more clearly, waving, cheering, shouting, cameras flashing... Rain lashes down. A CAPTION reads: "Sidney's Life, One Year Ago. Bafta Awards. London."
Looky-Loos. That's what They call you when you stand out in the rain all night just to catch a glimpse of Them going by. REVERSE - CELEBRITIES walk down the red carpet, pausing t wave at the fans.

I used to pretend it was different for me because I was getting paid by a magazine or newspaper, whatever. But that's, you know...I just loved watching Them. I'd stand outside looking in through the window and think what it would be like to somehow get inside. But there was only one way to get past the thin red line that separates the celebrities from the civilians. You had to be famous. 3.
Sidney stands talking to a young PR WOMAN at the security gate. He has a small, ugly PIG on a leash.
Babe?
Babe Three. Yeah. She looks doubtfully at the pig.
Babe was a cute little piglet.
Harry Potter used to be a cute little piglet too. What do you want? Tempus Fugits...
He hasn't got any ID.
How many pigs are coming tonight? Look, I was told to bring him, hand him over to the producer, Bob Milton, inside. You want me  to leave him here with you, that's fine...
No, you can't leave him with me. I've got...Hold on, I'll... She looks around, helplessly. She begins to unhook the re rope. Sidney tries to hide his excitement.
If you're positive that you're supposed to... An OLDER PR WOMAN stalks over.
Well, well, Sidney Young.
Well, well...clipboard Nazi-type woman. She turns to the SECURITY standing beside them.
The pig doesn't get in. 4. She starts to walk away.
What about me?
I was talking about you.
Sidney and the Pig are being "escorted" away from the red carpet by the Security.

The Looky-Loos dream is that one day they will somehow get to mingle with the stars. But the Industry can't allow any mingling. Stars have to be kept away from civilians, have to be quarantined, so they don't become normal. Like us. They pass a ravishing HOLLYWOOD ACTRESS walking the other way. She looks curiously at the pig as she passes. Sidney stares after her, longingly.
TRACKING through the doors and into the lobby of the exclusive hotel.

But after the awards come the parties - the Miramax Party, the London Records Party and, best of all - the Sharps Magazine Party, so exclusive that there are no pass-alongs, no plus-ones, no press. We find Sidney checking in at the desk.
(to Receptionist,
How much? I only want to stay for one night!
Sidney stands in the rising elevator, suit bag in his han holdall at his feet.
This is where the movie stars can finally relax, secure in the knowledge they are among their own kind. We see the PIG'S SNOUT poking out of the zip of the holdall.
Sidney turns from the mirror to face us. He is wearing a WAITER'S UNIFORM of white shirt, waistcoat, and bow tie. is also wearing a WIG and FALSE MOUSTACHE.
And that is when I strike. He picks up a tray of canapes from the bed and looks down to where the Pig watches him from the floor.
I want you in bed by ten. And no porn. He tosses the pig one of the canapes.

Sidney, tray in hand, peers around the corner to the entrance to the hotel's roofed COURTYARD. The Older PR Woman we saw earlier stands at the door, a formidable presence. As we watch she greets an approaching CELEBRITY gushingly. Seizing his chance Sidney darts towards the do and, tray held aloft to cover his face, slips through int the courtyard beyond.

...as Sidney emerges from the washrooms, now dressed only in the white shirt and black trousers. He scoops up a passing glass of champagne, checks his moustache and surveys the courtyard - a room full of glamour: tanned skin, diamonds, beautiful dresses, beautiful suits, champagne. He stands surveying the crowd of A-list celebrities in front of him, dazed.
You can do this. You belong here. You're a star. You're a big, bright shining star... 6.
The room is trashed - furniture over-turned, mini-bar ope and broken bottles all over the floor. A weird squealing which could almost be human is coming from the bathroom.
Hello? Sir? The squealing stops.

Is everything alright? The door opens and the Assistant Manager walks in and stands staring around him in horror. Behind him the pig emerges from the bathroom and slips out of the open door, across the corridor and straight into the open lift...
Sidney is talking to a very famous and very drunk Hollywo ACTRESS.
No, when I'm in L.A. I stay at the Sunset Marquis, when I'm here I always stay at the Sanderson. It's, you know, I don't feel at home these days unless I'm in a hotel.
So what do you do?
Oh, I'm a writer. Movie writer.
Oh great.

Yeah. Got one in pre-production now. You know it's really weird running into you like this because just the other day I was telling the producer I thought you'd be perfect for the lead. She starts to laugh.
No, seriously, you would, because, you know, you have this mixture of intelligence and beauty and fragility that we're looking for and, uh... 7.
What's the film?
Tits of Fury. She laughs.
I'm joking, I'm just...It's a bio- pic. About Greta Garbo. That's why I thought of you. You have those amazing cheek-bones and...are they real? Have you had plastic surgery?
No. Have you?
Me? No, hardly anything. A penis reduction as a child, that's pretty much... She laughs again, snorting into her drink. Sidney can't believe this - she likes him!

The lift doors glide open and the Pig trots out and aroun the corner. The PR Woman is still at the door to the courtyard, berating one of her staff. The Pig sails past them both, unnoticed, and disappears into the party.
A YOUNG MAN sits drinking at a table. He slips a little b of Ecstasy from his pocket and takes one.
As the Young Man pushes the bag back into his pocket. The Pig sits at his feet watching as the little bag slips bac out and DROPS to the floor. The Pig sniffs at the bag...
...still talking. The place is crammed now, and hot. Sidn wipes sweat from his forehead.
Oh god, I'm drunk.
Are you? 8.
I'm so drunk. I haven't eaten and...
You feel okay? Because my room's just upstairs if you want to lie down or, or loosen any, you know, morals or...
What is your name again?
Clark. Clark Baxter. He takes a sip of his champagne and his moustache comes loose and hangs limply from his face.

How'd you do? The Actress stares at him in surprise but Sidney doesn't notice - he is staring past her to where there is somethi of a COMMOTION amongst the guests. The PR Woman is hurryi across the room, hissing into her ear-piece. Somebody screams. Then to Sidney's horror a group of guests scatte in panic and the cause of the commotion is revealed: the Pig charges into view, heading straight for him.
Oh, shit... The Pig suddenly skids to a halt and stares at Sidney wit hot eyes. The PR Woman follows the Pig's gaze and spots Sidney.
Sarah, get security! Code Red. Sidney Young got in!
Who's Sidney Young? Before Sidney can answer the Pig charges.
Oh, shit! Sidney turns and legs it.

We are looking OVER THE SHOULDER of a tall grey-haired MA who stands in the shadows watching Sidney run past. This CLAYTON HARDING, his face hidden for the time being. 9. He lights a cigarette with a thoughtful air and watches Sidney's flight, rolling the BOOK OF MATCHES between his fingers.

...as the Pig catches up with him and lunges at his ankle Sidney screams, trips and flies through the air, wig spinning free, hurtling straight towards a table of startled celebrities. We FREEZE FRAME. SUPERED TITLE - "How To Lose Friends & Alienate People." We hear the opening of David Bowie's Star.
As the TITLES and song continue we see a protesting Sidne and Pig being escorted by Security through the endless corridors of the Hotel. Titles End. FADE OUT.
A seedy flat in Shepherds bush.

Sidney lies in bed reading a newspaper in his underwear. phone is RINGING in the next room. Sidney begins to cut out a photograph from one of the papers - Sidney struggling with an irate Clint Eastwood a some Security Men. The phone continues to ring.
Will you get that? (Beat) Will you get the phone? Sighing he gets up and scratching himself, stumbles throu to...

...which we see is, bizarrely, an OFFICE - full of an odd assortment of JOURNALISTS, desks, antiquated computers an an old fax machine. The walls are lined with past covers from Sidney's magazine - The Post-Modern Review. One bear a photograph of Victoria Beckham with the title "Posh Spice? Like Fuck She Is." 10. A JOURNALIST is talking on the phone by the door. The oth phone is still ringing.

Look, we don't hate celebrities at the Post-Modern Review, okay? We just don't think they should be taking themselves so seriously. For us a celebrity is a text to be deconstructed. Apart from Costner obviously. Sidney edges past him to where a LARGE WOMAN and a histrionic THIN MAN are in the middle of a argument, encouraged by the other members of staff.
I wouldn't do this the honour of calling it a review. It's a puerile, personal attack in, in alcoholic prose, in which incidentally you manage to misquote both Derrida and Lyotard. I am a...
Girl.
...an internationally respected academic and...
Prick.
...author of a very well received book on the history of culture and a...
Fuckwit.
(threading his way past) Couldn't one of you answer the phone? As the argument continues behind him he reaches the phone with a bored YOUNG MAN sitting by it.
Will you answer that? What do I pay you for?
You don't pay me. 11.
Just get the phone! The Young Man answers the phone.
Post-Modern Review.
Sidney, if she doesn't apologise I'm quitting.
(to the Large Woman) George can't leave. You'll have to apologise.
Why can't George leave?
He owns the fax machine. Sidney notices the Young Man is staring at him with a scared expression.
What?
It's Sharps Magazine. Sidney stops smiling.
We're finished.
We're not finished.
They sue, we're finished.
Shut up. (To the others) Will you be quiet! They ignore him and continue bickering. Sidney picks up t phone.
Sidney Young.
(over phone, gravel
This is Clayton Harding. I'm the editor of Sharps Magazine. Sidney is visibly thrown. 12.
Ah, Lord Vader.

SHOOTING FROM BEHIND Clayton Harding's swivel chair - all we can see is Clayton's grey hair, his custom-built desk and the enormous office in front of him. He is smoking. A he talks he rolls a BOOK OF MATCHES between his fingers.
I saw you at my party, just before you ruined it with your little pig stunt.
You liked that?

Sure. On his desk we see a few copies the Post-Modern Review - glimpses of stars on the covers - Catherine Zeta-Jones, Orlando Bloom... Clayton's hand sifts one copy from the others and holds it up - the cover depicts CLAYTON HIMSEL patrician handsome, stern, photo-shopped so that he appea to be NAKED. A headline reads "Clayton Harding - The Editor's New Clothes? Clayton's shoulder's heave with a snort of repressed laughter.
(examining the cover) I especially liked the part where Clint Eastwood beat the shit outa ya.
Sidney lights a cigarette, trying to seem casual.

We're not scared of you, Harding. You want to sue, go ahead and sue. It's like Jimmy Stewart said, (a poor Stewart impersonation:)"You sit up there and you spin your little webs and you think the whole world revolves around you and your money. Well, it doesn't, Mr... Mr... 13.
Clayton is still flicking through the magazines.
Potter.
"Mr. Potter..."You go ahead and sue if you want, but I warn you, if you strike me down, I shall become more powerful than you can possibly imagine. An ASSISTANT walks in. Clayton looks up.
Miss Taylor is here sir. Clayton nods and quickly throws the magazines into a BOTT DRAWER of the desk. Sidney is still talking over the phon beginning to enjoy himself.
Destroy me and a hundred more will spring up in my place - men who care nothing for success, men who cannot be bought, men whose only loyalty is to...
I want you to come and work for me at Sharps Magazine in New York.
Sidney stares to where the Thin Man is trying to get out the door with the Fax Machine, the Large Woman struggling with him. The two fall to the floor. The rest of the staf gather around them.
Fight, fight, fight...
Um...could you say that again please? We hear the sound of an aeroplane engine build as we...

head_text.subj: AN AEROPLANE ROARS THROUGH THE BLUE SKY. 23

text: Sidney emerges from the airport, wearing his crumpled bro suit, dragging his suitcase behind him. He stares around, excited to be here.
Sidney drags his suitcase down the quiet street and stops outside an apartment block, checking the address.
An elderly Polish lady - MRS KOWALSKI - is leading Sidney up the stairs of the building.
This magazine you are working for? It is good?
It's Sharps Magazine. You know Sharps? It's sort of society, fashion, crime, finance, Hollywood celebrities...
Hollywood. Sodom and Gomorrah. Now everybody is celebrity. You take out your breasts, you are celebrity.
(eyeing her chest
Well, I think it depends on the breasts but...
In Poland, someone was famous because they had done something...Marie Curie...Pope John Paul...

Yeah, they don't make entertainers like that any more... Mrs Kowalski cuffs the back of his head. Sidney is somewh surprised by this familiarity, having only just met the lady. She opens an apartment door.  15.
Mrs Kowalski shows Sidney into the small and cheaply furnished apartment. Sidney's boxed possessions stand in corner.
They brought your things yesterday.
Yup, this is good. This is...I can put my drum kit just over there and, uh... She stares at him.
That's a...that's just a joke. They're just little...congas.
When do you start work?
Tomorrow morning.
Well, you need to be fresh, make a good impression.(Leaving) Go to bed.
Just what I'm going to do...

A drunken Sidney dances frenetically on a small dance flo made of squares of flashing color, compensating with enthusiasm for what he lacks in coordination. The women o the floor shuffle further and further away from him.
Sidney walks down the street, staring bright eyed at the city around him, in love with New York. A SEXY WOMAN in a short dress passes him. Sidney ogles her as she walks int a BAR.
Sidney finds the Sexy Woman sitting at the bar. There is empty stool beside her. Sidney sidles into it. 16.
A Kona please. Sidney gestures to the Barman to make it two. He sits trying to think of something to say. The barman returns with their drinks.
(raising his glass) Hi, my name's Clark. Clark Baxter. The Woman looks at him without expression. Sidney sips hi drink, grimaces.
What the hell's that?
That's a water sir.

Well that's...that's not right, is it? That's not...put a dash of beer in that. A young woman has been sitting on the other side of Sidne This is ALISON OLSEN (20s) smart, attractive, dressed in elegant but no-nonsense suit. She is writing in a NOTEBOO She looks up and notices Sidney.
I'm sorry, my boyfriend's sitting there. Sidney gets up and examines the stool.
Is he? He's fucking small isn't he? He smiles at the Sexy Woman, hoping to get a laugh. Aliso examines Sidney coolly, points to the drink on the bar in front of Sidney.
That's his White Russian. He'll be here in a second.
Can you reserve these seats?
Nope. Sidney sits down and turns back to the Sexy Woman. 17.
I'm a journalist. Work for a little periodical you might have heard of called Sharps Magazine? Sidney produces a card and waves it vaguely.
I'm the Cultural Editor. Alison takes the card from his hand before he can put it away again.
(to Sexy Woman) This is a library card. (Reading it) From Glow-cester...
(snatching it back) That's...not that one... (Searching wallet) I've got it somewhere...I just... The Sexy Woman gets up and walks away. Sidney watches her go bitterly.
Happy now?
Just doing my bit for the gene pool. He produces the PHOTOGRAPH of him being held in a headloc by Clint Eastwood.
Who's that there with Clint Eastwood?
Morgan Freeman?
No, in the headlock.
You had this laminated?
Oh just give it... He snatches the photograph back, catching Alison's glass the process. Her drink SPILLS over her notebook - soaking the page she has been writing.
Shit! 18.
It's okay. It's okay. I've got it. He tries to blot the page with a napkin, smearing the ink
Just...just leave it! She examines the book, furious.
Sorry. He tries to think of something to say.
It's pronounced Gloucester by the way.
Are you going to get off that seat?
No.
Do you know the meaning of Karma?
The curry?
(inscribing a circle in

What goes around, comes around. The moment is approaching when you will pay the price for being an asshole. When my boyfriend gets here I'm going to put my pacifist leanings to one side and encourage him to take you outside and... Her cell-phone rings. She answers it.
Hello? Hi, honey.(Beat) Oh. (Beat) no, no, it's...don't worry about it. I'll see you then. She hangs up, avoiding Sidney's gaze, embarrassed and annoyed.
Boyfriend not coming? 19. She stares straight ahead, gathering her things.
Listen, I'm sorry. Do you think...? She turns to him.
Do you think I could have his drink? Alison gives him a cold smile, controlling her temper. Sh spots a heavily made-up WOMAN walking past.
Bobbie?
Hey!
You want a seat? I'm just leaving.
Thanks. The Woman takes Alison's place at the bar.
(to the newcomer) Hello. He slides the PHOTOGRAPH over to her.
Guess who that is with Clint Eastwood. Alison gives a small smile and leaves.
Sidney and the Woman dance drunkenly around the room to t music blaring from Sidney's stereo. The track finishes an they stand gasping for breath.

I'm gonna powder my nose. Why don't you put on something a little more romantic? She staggers off down the hall. Sidney, giddy with excitement, searches through some LPs and puts one on his old turntable. It's Ace of Spades by Motorhead. He stagge around, playing air-guitar for a moment. 20. The music is suddenly switched off. He turns to find Mrs Kowalski standing beside the record player, staring griml at him.
Mrs Lebowski...
Kowalski. You know what time it is? The music blaring, your door open...

(trying to seem sober) Was it? Fuck. I mean, shit. Sorry. I just...met an old friend and brought them back... The Woman staggers back into the room, her back to us. Sh is NAKED. She is also surprisingly muscular.
...for a little... He notices the woman. His gaze drops to below the waist.
...penis. Mrs Kowalski turns and takes in the view. Nobody moves.
A hung-over Sidney wakes up in his bed, light streaming through the window.
He examines his reflection, psyching himself up for his first day.
You can do this! You can do this! He hums the fanfare from the Rocky theme.

Sidney walks into the room, still humming the theme tune, shadow boxing. He opens the blinds and turns to the couch The "Woman" wakes up from where she has been sleeping on the couch and gazes blearily at Sidney.
Quick coffee Bob and then you've got to go. 21. We hear the opening of Brian Ferry's version of The `In' Crowd as we...

As the song continues we see Sidney swagger down the busy sidewalk towards us. He is wearing sunglasses and a T-shi emblazoned with a photograph of Keanu Reeves and the caption "Young, Dumb and Full of Cum."The T-shirt is ridi up a little over his belly.
This is my city. He stops at a gleaming chrome entrance and stares up at t Heywood Building towering above him.

As the song continues Sidney, still swaggering, is escort through the formidable looking security by a thin and chi ASSISTANT. The entrance hall arches above them, a vast an impressive cavern of chrome and glass.
This is my building.

Sidney leans nonchalantly against the wall of the lift examining the Chic Assistant and two stunningly beautiful MODELS who are in conversation. Sidney manages to catch t attention of one of the models and flashes what he believ is a rakish smile. In return he receives an icy glare.
These are my models.

The Chic Assistant leads Sidney down a curving, red carpeted corridor, past a chrome wall inscribed with the giant logo of the magazine. They reach a set of double doors which the Assistant opens for Sidney...
And this... Sidney walks through into...
Harding swings around in his chair to glare at us, a cigarette in his mouth. 22.
...is my Boss.
What the fuck are you wearing? The song grinds to an abrupt halt. Sidney loses a quantit of swagger. He examines his T-shirt.
You like it? I brought you one. He takes a T-shirt from his satchel and hands it to Harding.
Thanks. Casually he flings the shirt out of the open window behin him.
Next time you come here dressed like that, you follow the shirt. You understand? Sidney nods dumbly.
Sit down. How was the flight?
Good. Thanks for the business class tickets, Clay. Harding regards him gravely.
That was a mistake. And don't call me Clay.
Oh. Well, if it's any consolation I got downgraded anyway.
That is some consolation. Sidney notices that the copy of The Post-Modern Review is on the desk - Clayton NAKED.
Ha! That was just a little, uh... as it happens I'm a big fan of your earlier, funnier work. Snipe Magazine that was...that was really good. 23. Harding stares at Sidney.
Yeah, you've...you've actually been a big influence on me and I really think together we can inject a bit of that Snipe spirit into this magazine. Now I've got a few ideas that I'd like to...

You think you've arrived, doncha? Well I hate to break it to you, but you're only in the first room. It's not nothing, don't get me wrong, but there are plenty of people in this town who never made it past the first room. After a year or so, maybe longer, you'll discover a secret doorway at the back of the first room that leads to the second. Eventually, if you're lucky, you'll discover another doorway back of the second room that leads to the third. He gazes at Sidney through narrowed eyes.
There are seven rooms in all. You're in the first, I'm in the seventh, and doncha forget it Sidney has been listening with a frown of concentration.
So...if I make it to the Seventh Room - will I become a true Jedi Knight? Harding exhales smoke and puts out his cigarette.
Which brings us to the subject of your sense of humour. I had a look through your "magazine" here.
What'd you think? Clayton swivels in his chair and stares thoughtfully out over the Manhattan skyline.
Oh, I thought it was...kinda snarky. And bitter. And... witless. 24. Sidney digests this. Clayton seems lost in thought. Finally...
I'm going to try you out in the I Spy Section.

Sidney is hurrying to keep up with LAWRENCE MADDOX (40's) as he strides down the corridor. Lawrence is Canadian, handsome, one of the golden boys of the magazine and arrogant with it. Other EMPLOYEES pass them as they walk, heads down, expressions serious. The place is a model of quiet, professional industry.
(glancing at Sidney's
Well, Sidney. We've only just met but already I perceive I am in the presence of a rare comic sensibility.
Thanks.

I know your Hi-jinx gave you a certain notoriety back in Olde England but things are going to be a bit different here. Harding wants me to be your Rabbi, show you the ropes. Are you aware of what we do at I Spy?
You photograph famous people when they're drunk?

I Spy is the nation's window onto High Society. The Looky-Loos read us because...well, They Weren't There. The Glitterati read us because we tell them They Were There. For this system to work we have to know where There is.
So...when we go out to clubs and things...would that, would that be on expenses or...?
This isn't a vacation. It's a vocation. 25. Maddox sweeps around the corner into an open-plan office area. Fact-checkers and Assistants buzz around.
When we do go out you're going to have to wear something more suitable.
Okay. What do you mean by suitable? Maddox gestures at Sidney's body.
Something that covers all of this up. He starts to check messages on his desk. Sidney, trying t seem at ease, stares at a black and white PHOTOGRAPH on t wall.
Is that Mussolini?
(Beat.) ) No, Sidney, that's Richard Heywood. The owner of this magazine.
Oh. Looks a little like, uh...(pointing to the child in the photograph, smiling) Who's this funny looking kid? Is that his son? Maddox stares at him.
That's his daughter, Elizabeth; now my wife. A SUBTITLE materializes like a halo around Maddox's head. It reads: Do Not Fuck with Me.
Really? Well, she's very...isn't she? Really, very... Someone walks up behind Sidney.

Miss Olsen here takes care of the gallery openings, book launches and other intellectual fare. Can you find our new rookie something to do? 26. Sidney turns to find Alison behind him, eating an apple. She eyes him coldly.
I hear the Cultural Editor's job is up for grabs?
Alison sits working at her computer. Sidney appears and perches on the edge of her desk.
Listen, seeing as how I'm going to be sitting just over there, don't you think we should try and put last night behind us?
No. Get off my desk.
I'm not sure what I'm supposed to be doing. (Beat) Are you going to help me out?
Okay. Which way did you come in? Sidney stares at her. Alison takes some contact sheets fr her desk and shoves them at him.
Chris Blick exhibition opening. Caption it. Now get off my desk. One of the magazines gorgeous Fashionistas - INGRID - wal past.
Hi!
Hi, Ingrid. Ingrid stares at Sidney's outfit, thrown.
(a wolfish smile) You going to introduce me?
This is Clark Baxter. (Noticing Ingrid's gaze) He's English.
(That explains it) Ohh...right. 27.
Actually it's Sidney. Sidney Young. Clark Baxter is my alias.
Why do you have an alias?
He uses it when he's trying to pick up transsexuals.
Nice to meet you. She walks on.
I take it you knew about Bob and didn't tell me? Alison inscribes a circle in the air with her finger without looking up.
Sidney is on the phone. He is staring at some contact sheets.
Hello, is that the Parsons Gallery?
Yes, it is. This is Celia Parsons speaking.

This is Sidney Young from Sharps Magazine? We're running some photographs from your opening of the Chris Blick exhibition, and I just need to caption them. I was wondering if you could help me identify some of the people?
All right.
Thanks. So...Chris Blick. Man or woman?
What? 28.
Is Chris Blick a man or woman?
Are you sure you're calling from Sharps magazine?
Yes, I am.
Tell me Stanley, why have they given you this assignment if you don't know who one of the most famous artists in America is?
I...I don't really know.
He's a man.
Okay. Is he an old man?
He's an older man, yes.
(staring at a
Okay, I've got two old men here - so is he the fat one?
You do realize that Clayton Harding is a personal friend of mine?
What's that got to do with anything?
Right. She hangs up. Beat. Sidney looks around, hoping no-one wa listening. He re-dials.
Parsons gallery.
Is he the one with the wonky eye? 29. She hangs up again.

Sidney, coming back from lunch, gets into the lift eating HAMBURGER. Another of the magazine's Fashionistas - ANNA gets into the lift and tries to hold the door open for an approaching friend. The doors swish shut, Anna pulling he hand out of the way just in time. The lift rises.
It's fashion sensitive. If you're not wearing Prada it'll take your arm clean off. Anna stares at this strange man with the burger, baffled.

But I am wearing Prada. The lift stops and she gets out. Alison gets in, sees Sidney and winces. She takes out a book and pretends to read. The lift begins to rise again. Through it's glass doors we see the different floors passing, different publications - each a hive of sober, hard work. Sidney stares at them.
This isn't what I expected. Alison recoils slightly.
What did you expect?
I don't know. The Algonquin circle. Dorothy Parker. Martinis. Quips. Look at them. Not one of them is drunk.
It's called being a professional. You should try it some time.
There's something you should understand. I'm not really one of you.
By "you" do you mean "human?" 30.
I mean the glossy posse. Bunch of Zombies, writing about "Pets of the Stars" but acting like they're working for the UN. I'm here to shake things up a bit. Where are you from?
Not that it's any of your business, but I'm from Port Huron, Michigan.
